case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Assam v. Smt. Jyotikana Chowdhurani

facts.text: Six appeals with certificates of fitness under section 66A(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act XI of 1922 are directed against a common judgment and order passed by the Full Bench of the High Court of Judicature in Assam.

anchor.surface_text: Bhagwati, J. These six appeals with certificates of fitness under section 66A 2  of the Indian Income-tax Act  XI of 1922  are directed against a companymon judgment and order passed by the Full Bench of the High Court of Judicature in Assam

facts.text: High Court Full Bench delivered judgment on consolidated reference by Income-tax Appellate Tribunal under section 66(1), with Sarjoo Prasad C.J. and Ram Labhaya J. answering referred question in affirmative, Deka J. in negative.

anchor.surface_text: delivered on a companysolidated reference by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal under section 66 1  of the Act whereby Sarjoo Prasad, C.J., and Ram Labhaya, J., answered the referred question in the affirmative and Deka, J., answered it in the negative.

facts.text: Referred question: Whether on the facts and circumstances receipts from sale of sal trees can be said to be agricultural income under section 2(1) and exempt under section 4(3)(viii) of Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The referred question wa Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of this case the receipts from the sale of sal trees can be said to be agricultural income under section 2 1  and exempt from taxation under section 4 3  viii  of the Income-tax Ac ?

facts.text: Mechpara Estate situate in District of Goalpara, Assam, assessed to land revenue payable to State of Assam and subject to local rates collected by Assam Government officers.

anchor.surface_text: Smt. Jyotikana Chowdhurani, the respondent in Civil Appeal No. 51 of 1956, is the widow and legal representative of the late Jyotsna Nath Choudhury who was a companysharer and proprietor of the Mechpara Estate situate in the District of Goalpara in the State of Assam.

facts.text: Estate has vast areas of forest tracts, considerable portions covered mainly by sal trees.

anchor.surface_text: The said estate has vast areas of forest tracts, companysiderable portions of which are companyered mainly by sal trees.

facts.text: Trees in the forests are of spontaneous growth, no planting or sowing or employment of any human agency for tilling the soil.

anchor.surface_text: The trees in the forests are of spontaneous growth and there was numberplanting or sowing or employment of any human agency for the purpose of tilling the soil.

facts.text: In 1923, Income-tax Officer assessed late Rai Sourindra Narayan Sinha Chowdhury on receipts from sale of sal trees, but Assistant Commissioner on April 28, 1923 held receipts agricultural income, accepted and not assessed for years.

anchor.surface_text: The late Rai Sourindra Narayan Sinha Chowdhury father of Shri Jyotirindra Narayan Sinha Choudhury was a companysharer of Parbat Joar Estate, and had been assessed by the Income-tax Officer in the year 1923, on receipts from the sale of sal trees from his forests as income within the meaning of the Indian Income-tax Act. The Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax on appeal held by his order dated April 28, 1923,

facts.text: Jyotsna Nath Chowdhury assessed by ITO Gauhati on December 17, 1946 for 1946-47 on receipts from sale of sal trees.

anchor.surface_text: On December 17, 1946, the said Jyotsna Nath Chowdhury was assessed for the year 1946-47 to income on his receipts from the sale of sal trees from his forests by the Income-tax Officer, Gauhati.

facts.text: Appeal by Jyotsna Nath Chowdhury against ITO assessment failed, further appeal to Tribunal failed.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal filed by him against the said order of assessment failed and so did a further appeal filed by him to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Calcutta.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to High Court under s66(1) on consolidated statement including other respondents.

anchor.surface_text: He thereupon asked for a reference by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal of certain questions of law arising out of its order under section 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act. The Tribunal drew up a companymon statement of case in regard to the assessments of the said Jyotsna Nath Chowdhury as also the other respondents

facts.text: Birendra Narayana Chowdhury assessed on December 17, 1946 for 1946-47 by ITO Gauhati on sal tree sales.

anchor.surface_text: Birendra Narayana Chowdhury, the respondent in C.A. No. 58 of 1956, was a companysharer proprietor of the same estate. He also was assessed on December 17, 1946, to income-tax on his receipts from the sale of sal trees from his forests for the year 1946-47 by the Income-tax Officer, Gauhati.

facts.text: Jagadindra Narayan Chowdhury assessed March 24, 1947 for 1946-47 by ITO Gauhati on sal tree sales; appeal to AAC, died pendency, AAC reduced March 15, 1948; Tribunal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: On March 24, 1947, the said Jagadindra Narayan Chowdhury was assessed to income-tax on his receipts from the sale of sal trees from his forests for the year 1946-47 by the Income-tax Officer, Gauhati. He preferred an appeal before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax, Calcutta B Range, but died during the pendency of the said appeal and was succeeded by his mother - the respondent. The Appellate Income-tax Commissioner, Calcutta B Range, by his order dated March 15, 1948, reduced the assessment.

facts.text: Trees sold were standing for considerable number of years, soil untouched.

anchor.surface_text: From all that was done to the trees it was clear that the trees sold were those standing for a companysiderable number of years during which the soil had remained untouched.

facts.text: Assessees made no contribution by way of cultivation in production of income.

anchor.surface_text: In the production of the income the applicants made numbercontribution by way of cultivation.

facts.text: Assessees claimed employment of human skill and labour for maintenance, preservation, nursing, improving, rearing of forests.

anchor.surface_text: The applicants case, however, was that there had been employment of human skill and labour with respect to the forests. Apart from the fact of the maintenance of a forest establishment, it was claimed that human skill and labour were employed for the maintenance, preservation, nursing, improving and rearing of the forests,

facts.text: Activities claimed: reservation of blocks (Jhars) operated by rotation cyclic order, marking trees fit for felling, creeper cutting, thinning diseased trees, clearing undergrowth, allowing grazing Kartik to Chaitra, burning undergrowth March-April, protection from fire, closure rainy season, preservation mother trees.

anchor.surface_text: It is claimed by the applicants in their petition which was filed before the Tribunal on 22nd June, 1951, in reply to the draft statement of case that the following activities with reference to the forests were taken recourse t  a  reservation of blocks of forest companymonly known as Jhars and their operation in these blocks by rotation  cyclic order   b  marking of trees fit for felling  c  creeper and climber cutting  d  thinning and removal of diseased and unsound trees  e  clearing of jungles and undergrowth  f  allowing grazing from Kartik to Chaitra  g  burning of undergrowths in March April  which clears the jungles and fertilises the soil   h  protection from fire - maintenance of fire lines closure of all forests to men and cattle during rainy season Baisakh to Aswin and  j  preservation of mother trees.

facts.text: Affidavit filed before Tribunal, but actual costs not found in books.

anchor.surface_text: In order to establish these facts an affidavit was filed before the Tribunal at the time of hearing of the appeal. But the actual companyts with reference to each activity companyld number be found from the books of the assessee

facts.text: No sum contributed towards cultivation.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that numbersum was companytributed towards cultivation.

facts.text: For Mechpara Estate, expenses on forest establishment including temporary hands estimated Rs. 15,000 a year, gross receipts Rs. 1,70,000.

anchor.surface_text: It may be numbered that on the question of the employment of human skill and labour, the appellants representative stated before the Tribunal that with regard to the Mechpara Estate, the expenses on forests establishment  including temporary hands  were estimated at Rs. 15,000 a year, the gross receipts being about Rs. 1,70,000.

facts.text: For Parbatjoar Estate, gross receipts Rs. 3,32,414, spent Rs. 14,057 on forest officers, guards, head officers.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to Parbatjoar Estate, whose gross receipts companye to Rs. 3,32,414, the appellants representative stated that a total sum of Rs. 14,057 had been spent on the following head 8 Forest Officers and 18 Barkandajas Rs. 5,219 32 Forest Guards Rs. 4,838 Proportionate salary of the Head Officers Rs. 4,000 ----- Total Rs. 14,057

facts.text: Supreme Court holds no planting or sowing, no tilling, no basic operations, only subsequent forestry operations on spontaneous growth.

anchor.surface_text: Applying the principles which we have enunciated in that judgment to the facts of the instant cases, it appears that there was numberplanting or sowing of the seeds number was any human agency employed for the purpose of tilling the soil. The soil had remained untouched and in the production of the income the assessees had made numbercontribution by way of cultivation. There were numberbasic operations either which were performed by the assessees on the forest lands.

facts.text: Operations were for maintenance etc. of spontaneous forests, not converting to agricultural.

anchor.surface_text: What was done by them was the performance of forestry operations which were in the nature of subsequent operations, operations which were performed after the produce had sprouted form the soil. The forests companytinued to be forests of spontaneous growth and the only result of the performance of these operations on the produce of the forests which was the outcome of spontaneous growth unaided by human skill and labour was the maintenance, preservation, nursing, improving and rearing of the forests.

facts.text: Costs insignificant: Mechpara <8%, Parbatjoar <4% of gross income.

anchor.surface_text: We are fortified in this companyclusion if regard be had to the fact that he forestry operations which were performed by the assessees were of insignificant value as companypared with the gross receipts derived by them from the sale of the forest trees. In the case of Mechpara Estate the companyts of these operations did number even companye to 8 per cent. and in the case of the Parbatjoar Estate even to 4 per cent. of the gross income.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeals, answers question in negative.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the decision reached by the majority of the Judges of the high Court was number companyrect and it ought to be set aside. The appeals will, therefore, be allowed and the referred question will be answered in the negative.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of this case the receipts from the sale of sal trees can be said to be agricultural income under section 2 1 and exempt from taxation under section 4 3 viii of the Income-tax Ac

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of this case the receipts from the sale of sal trees can be said to be agricultural income under section 2 1  and exempt from taxation under section 4 3  viii  of the Income-tax Ac ?

issues.text: whether the operations which the assessees claim to have performed in these forests were agricultural operations such as to bring the income derived from these forests within the definition of agricultural income

anchor.surface_text: We shall however proceed on the basis that these facts were proved by the assessees and determine whether the operations which the assessees claim to have performed in these forests were agricultural operations such as to bring the income derived from these forests within the definition of agricultural income.

issues.text: the connotation of the terms agriculture and agricultural purpose and the conditions under which the forestry operations performed by the assessee on forests of spontaneous growth can be assimilated to agricultural operations so as to constitute the income derived from the sale of the forest trees agricultural income within the meaning of its definition in section 2 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: the connotation of the terms agriculture and agricultural purpose and the conditions under which the forestry operations performed by the assessee on forests of spontaneous growth can be assimilated to agricultural operations so as to constitute the income derived from the sale of the forest trees agricultural income within the meaning of its definition in section 2 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act

Apart from the fact of the maintenance of a forest establishment, it was claimed that human skill and labour were employed for the maintenance, preservation, nursing, improving and rearing of the forests,

arguments.claim: Even without tilling or planting, forestry operations conducive to growth involve human skill on land, making land used for agricultural purposes and income exempt

anchor.surface_text: On these facts the majority of the Judges held that even though there was no tilling of the land or planting of seeds or saplings and the trees were of spontaneous germination, the operations carried on by the assessees were conducive to the growth and development of the trees and in essence involved the expenditure of human skill and labour on the land itself.

arguments.court_reasoning: Ratio erroneous; operations not basic, cannot convert spontaneous growth to agriculture

arguments.claim: No evidence for claims of human skill and labour; affidavits unreliable without means to test

anchor.surface_text: Even though Sarjoo Prasad, C.J., and Ram Labhaya, J., proceeded on the basis that these facts were proved, Deka, J., struck a dissenting note and observed that there was no evidence as to the claim made by the respondents and that the statements made on affidavit could not be accepted as there was no means to test them.

arguments.claim: Expenses on forest operations insignificant relative to gross receipts (Mechpara ~8%, Parbatjoar ~4%), indicating not substantial cultivation

anchor.surface_text: It may be noted that on the question of the employment of human skill and labour, the appellants representative stated before the Tribunal that with regard to the Mechpara Estate, the expenses on forests establishment including temporary hands were estimated at Rs. 15,000 a year, the gross receipts being about Rs. 1,70,000.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: umber companyrect and it ought to be set aside. The appeals will, therefore, be allowed and the referred question will be answered in the negative. Th

arguments.court_reasoning: Fortifies conclusion that operations insignificant compared to receipts

arguments.claim: Forestry operations on spontaneous forests are subsequent operations after sprouting, not basic operations required for agriculture; income not agricultural under section 2(1)

anchor.surface_text: The connotation of the terms agriculture and agricultural purpose and the conditions under which the forestry operations performed by the assessee on forests of spontaneous growth can be assimilated to agricultural operations so as to constitute the income derived from the sale of the forest trees agricultural income within the meaning of its definition in section 2 1 of the Indian Income-tax Act have been laid down by us in the judgment just delivered in Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal v. Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy.

arguments.claim: None of the listed operations (a to j) qualify as basic operations; cannot tack subsequent operations onto non-existent basic ones

anchor.surface_text: Out of the categories a to g set out in the statement of facts, none of the operations was assimilated to basic operations in agriculture and unless and until there was even one basic operation on the land itself the rest of the operations could not be tacked on to them so as to convert the whole of them into agricultural operations.

holdings.text: The referred question ought to have been answered in the negative: receipts from the sale of sal trees cannot be said to be agricultural income under section 2(1) and exempt under section 4(3)(viii) of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the ratio adopted by the majority of the judges of the High Court was erroneous and the referred question ought to have been answered in the negative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying principles from CIT v. Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy: no basic operations like planting/sowing/tilling; only subsequent forestry operations on spontaneous growth; specific operations not basic; insignificant costs fortify.

holdings.text: There were no basic operations performed by the assessees on the forest lands; soil untouched, no planting, sowing or tilling.

anchor.surface_text: Applying the principles which we have enunciated in that judgment to the facts of the instant cases, it appears that there was no planting or sowing of the seeds nor was any human agency employed for the purpose of tilling the soil. The soil had remained untouched and in the production of the income the assessees had made no contribution by way of cultivation. There were no basic operations either which were performed by the assessees on the forest lands.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of tests from prior judgment to admitted facts of spontaneous growth and lack of cultivation.

holdings.text: The operations performed were subsequent forestry operations after sprouting, for maintenance/preservation of spontaneous forests, not converting to agriculture.

anchor.surface_text: What was done by them was the performance of forestry operations which were in the nature of subsequent operations, operations which were performed after the produce had sprouted form the soil. The forests continued to be forests of spontaneous growth and the only result of the performance of these operations on the produce of the forests which was the outcome of spontaneous growth unaided by human skill and labour was the maintenance, preservation, nursing, improving and rearing of the forests.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Forestry activities foster growth but do not qualify as basic operations prerequisite for agriculture per Benoy Kumar principles.

holdings.text: None of the listed operations (a to g) qualify as basic operations in agriculture; subsequent operations cannot be tacked onto non-existent basic ones to make income agricultural.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the categories a to g set out in the statement of facts, none of the operations was assimilated to basic operations in agriculture and unless and until there was even one basic operation on the land itself the rest of the operations could not be tacked on to them so as to convert the whole of them into agricultural operations.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Examination of claimed activities against basic/subsequent distinction from prior precedent; no basic operation present.

holdings.text: The ratio of the majority judges of the High Court was erroneous; their decision set aside, appeals allowed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred in holding operations agricultural despite lack of basic cultivation; correct application of law requires negative answer.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal v. Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy

The soil had remained untouched and in the production of the income the assessees had made numbercontribution by way of cultivation.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal v. Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy
precedents.cited_proposition: The connotation of the terms agriculture and agricultural purpose and the conditions under which the forestry operations performed by the assessee on forests of spontaneous growth can be assimilated to agricultural operations so as to constitute the income derived from the sale of the forest trees agricultural income within the meaning of its definition in section 2 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the decision reached by the majority of the Judges of the high Court was number companyrect and it ought to be set aside. The appeals will, therefore, be allowed and the referred question will be answered in the negative.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals allowed; High Court decision set aside; referred question answered in the negative (receipts from sale of sal trees not agricultural income)
directions: Referred question answered in the negative
Appellant awarded one set of costs from respondents

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the ratio adopted by the majority of the judges of the High Court was erroneous and the referred question ought to have been answered in the negative.

We are therefore of opinion that the decision reached by the majority of the Judges of the high Court was number companyrect and it ought to be set aside. The appeals will, therefore, be allowed and the referred question will be answered in the negative.

Absence of basic operations in h2 supports characterization of operations as subsequent in h3.
Holding h2 on no basic operations addresses issue i2 of whether operations were agricultural.

anchor.surface_text: Applying the principles which we have enunciated in that judgment to the facts of the instant cases, it appears that there was no planting or sowing of the seeds nor was any human agency employed for the purpose of tilling the soil. The soil had remained untouched and in the production of the income the assessees had made no contribution by way of cultivation. There were no basic operations either which were performed by the assessees on the forest lands.

We are therefore of opinion that the decision reached by the majority of the Judges of the high Court was number companyrect and it ought to be set aside. The appeals will, therefore, be allowed and the referred question will be answered in the negative.

edges.explanation: Holding h3 on subsequent forestry operations supports c10's classification of income from spontaneous forests as non-agricultural.
Holding h3 that operations were subsequent supports holding h1 negative answer on agricultural income.
Subsequent maintenance operations in h3 support h4 that they do not qualify as basic.
Holding h3 on nature of operations addresses i2.

anchor.surface_text: What was done by them was the performance of forestry operations which were in the nature of subsequent operations, operations which were performed after the produce had sprouted form the soil. The forests continued to be forests of spontaneous growth and the only result of the performance of these operations on the produce of the forests which was the outcome of spontaneous growth unaided by human skill and labour was the maintenance, preservation, nursing, improving and rearing of the forests.

We are therefore of opinion that the decision reached by the majority of the Judges of the high Court was number companyrect and it ought to be set aside. The appeals will, therefore, be allowed and the referred question will be answered in the negative.

edges.explanation: Holding h4 that listed operations are not basic and cannot substitute supports c10's requirement of basic operations.

anchor.surface_text: t he forestry operations which were performed by the assessees were of insignificant value as companypared with the gross receipts derived by them fro

Holding h4 on operations not qualifying addresses i2.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the categories a to g set out in the statement of facts, none of the operations was assimilated to basic operations in agriculture and unless and until there was even one basic operation on the land itself the rest of the operations could not be tacked on to them so as to convert the whole of them into agricultural operations.

We are therefore of opinion that the decision reached by the majority of the Judges of the high Court was number companyrect and it ought to be set aside. The appeals will, therefore, be allowed and the referred question will be answered in the negative.
